sp.p: Pretty Sweetneſs! thou'rt grown out of my Knowledge too, to be ſure; but we have been better acquainted; I was thy Mother's Midwife.—Let me ſee—you will be Eighteen come the Time, and not married yet! Now out upon thy Father, for a naughty Man! it muſt have been his Fault, for you are ſo pretty, that you muſt have had Offers enow.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: It is ſoon enough to know Care and Trouble.

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p: Now out upon it! we have never had any good Times ſince People talk'd ſo.—Was not I young my ſelf? and don't I know that the moſt troubleſome and careful Part of a Woman's Life, is from the time that ſhe is fit for a Husband, till ſhe has got one? Our greateſt Care and Trouble is over then, for the Men, who ſeldom take any before, are bound to do it then.

div.head: AIR L. A Dame of Honour.

lg.l: A Maid, tho' beautiful and chaſte,
Man, like a Figure, by her plac'd,
Makes her Worth and Value known.
The Tyrant, Man, faſt bound for Life,
To rule ſhe takes upon her;
Whene'er a Maid is made a Wife,
She becomes a Dame of Honour.

sp.speaker: G. Coſt.
sp.p: Goody Buſy, you are always talking to People in praiſe of Marriage; now I ſuſpect you, being a Midwife, do it for your own Ends.—

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p: Suppoſe I did, Goody Coſtive, where is the Harm of that? I am ſure, Times are ſo bad, that what with one thing, and what with another, an honeſt Woman, in my way of Buſineſs, can hardly get Bread; and I never expect to ſee it otherwiſe, while Matrimony is ſo much deſpiſed as it is; why, the Men are grown ſo horrible cunning, that few of them will marry at all; and the Women are grown ſo forward, that they won't ſtay till they are married.—But you are melancholy, Mrs. Silvia.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: A little thoughtful; I hope you'll excuſe me.

sp.speaker: G. Gabble.
sp.p: Why truly, Neighbour Buſy, theſe muſt needs be great Hardſhips upon you; for no Marriages, no Lyings-Inn.

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p:
It is not that which I complain of; for, to ſay the Truth, I don't find but that ſingle People have as many Children as thoſe that are married; but then they are ſuch Infidels, as to let their Children dye without Chriſtening, and what ſignifies, to the Midwife, a Lying-in, without a Chriſtening?—I had once ſome Thoughts of going to London, but I am informed that it is worſe there than here; for there are, it ſeems,
a Number of Women who get their Livelihood by being naught with any Man that will pay them for it, and yet never have any Children at all.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I can't gueſs what my Father deſigns by ſending for theſe People. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: G. Coſt.
sp.p: Good lack-a-day! then they have no need of a Midwife, for certain.

sp.speaker: G. Buſy
sp.p: No, no; the Surgeons do all their Buſineſs.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Silvia, Goody Buſy, Goody Coſtive, Goody Gabble, and Jonathan.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Jonathan! What comes he for?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: To me?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; Sir John Freeman, by me, begs your Peruſal of this Letter.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I am ſorry Sir John has given himſelf the Trouble, ſince I am under the Neceſſity of refuſing it.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: My Maſter commanded me to tell you, that it concern'd the Happineſs of your Father.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Since ſuch is the Caſe, I'll this Inſtant to my Father, and acquaint him of this important Letter—wait you here my Return.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Well, ſhe's an agreeable Lady, faith. I wonder what Sir John means, by employing me in this Affair? If his Deſign be honourable, he knows I can be of no manner of uſe to him, 'tis quite out of my way; and if he has any other Thoughts of her, he has leſs Senſe than I imagin'd he had—But who have we here! my old Acquaintance, and former Neighbour, Goody Buſy!

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p: Bleſs me; Mr. Jonathan! is it you! why you are ſtrangely grown; almoſt out of my Knowledge. But I am glad to ſee thee, with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: I beg your Pardon, but I muſt ſalute you.

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p: 'Tis what we are us'd to at Chriſtenings.—Pray let it go round.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: G. Coſt.
sp.p: A pretty civil young Man truly. I have known ſome ſqueamiſh ill-bred Fellows, refuſe to do their Duty by a Woman, becauſe ſhe was in Years.

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p: But where haſt been all this while; and what Buſineſs doſt follow?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: As you ſee, I ſerve a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p: Are you Married?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: My Maſter is a ſingle Man, and won't keep any Body that is married in his Family.

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p: Ay, Shame take theſe Gentlefolks; they would have every Body as bad as themſelves. That muſt be a ſad Houſe, that has never an honeſt Woman in it.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: We live as they do in moſt Batchelors Families, very lovingly. While my Maſter is entertaining the Houſe-keeper in his Chamber, I am as civil to the Cook-maid in the Garret.

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p: O ſad, O ſad! what pity it is that young Men ſhould ſpend their Time unfruitfully with naughty Women; when, were they honeſtly married, they might in a lawful way do much good in their Generation. If you have any Thoughts of Marriage, I have a Widow in my Eye, that would do very well for you. She has ſomething to bring you to, and is under Thirty I aſſure you. While her Husband was in Health, ſhe brought him a Child every Year; but I don't know how it fell out, he grew weary of her, and, as it is ſuppos'd, thought to have kill'd her with Kindneſs: but as it always happens in thoſe Caſes, he did his own Buſineſs inſtead of hers, he fell into a Conſumption—and dy'd about a Month ago.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: No, Goody Buſy, that will never do for me; a wanton young Widow for a Wife, and a skittiſh Horſe for a long Journey, are two the moſt troubleſome things a Man can meet withal.

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p: Perhaps you would rather have a Maid. Truly they are tickliſh things, and I don't much care to meddle or make with 'em. But I do know of a Farmer's Daughter, that will fit you to a Hair. Her Father is a ſufficient Man, and will ſtock a Farm for you. 'Tis true, indeed, ſhe has had one Child; for I am a Woman of Integrity, and would not deceive any Body in theſe matters for the World. They did not marry her ſoon enough. But ſhe'll make an excellent ſtirring Wife, I'll warrant her.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: A Maid that has had a Child, is worſe than a Widow that's paſt it. I don't like any Body that you have propos'd half ſo well as yourſelf.

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p: Now out upon you, for an idle Pack. Why thou naughty, wanton, young Knave, what wouldſt thou do with me? Heaven help me, I am old, and fit for nothing.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Let me ask you a few Queſtions, and you'll find you are fit for every thing.

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p: Well, come on then.

div.head: AIR LI. Canſt thou not weave Bonelace.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.l: Thou canſt do Houſewife's Work!

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.l: Yea, by'r Lady, that I can.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.l: Whip and ſtitch with a Jerk?

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.l: Yea, as well as any one.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.l: Canſt thou not bake and brew?

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.l: Yea, by'r Lady, that I can.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.l: And do the other thing too?

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.l: Out, you're naughty: get you gone.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.l: Thou canſt break Jeſts, and ſing?

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.l: Yea, by'r Lady, that I can.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.l: Caper and Dance with a Spring?

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.l: Yea, as well as any one.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: Welford, Silvia, Jonathan, Goody Buſy, Goody Coſtive, &c.

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p: Come Neighbours, our Friends at Farmer Welford's expect us.—There is ſomething of Conſequence to be done; he would'n't ſend for us for nothing.—A Wedding, I hope; old Folks drop off apace, but if the young Ones would Marry, and be induſtrious, the World might ſtill be increaſing.
sp.l: By honeſt Love alone the World's upheld,
Death can't deſtroy ſo faſt, as Love can build.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I have obtained my Father's Leave to receive the Letter you have brought. Whether the Contents may require or deſerve an Anſwer, I ſhall take Time to conſider. I have no more to ſay.

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.stage: [Silvia gives the Letter to Welford, who reads it.]

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: See, my Silvia, the Picture of a Mind ſtruggling between a Senſe of Virtue, and the Love of Vice. Yet he entreats to ſee thee in ſuch Terms, as might move weak Minds to pity him.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: If Pity be a Weakneſs, I am, ſure, the weakeſt of my Sex; but yet I fear to ſee him.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: His baſe Attempt on thee, his avow'd Averſion to Marriage, and the Ruin of the Daughter of that honeſt Stranger whom we entertain'd, all ſhew the Juſtice of thy Fear.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: That Men ſhould know Vice to be an Evil, by the Pain it gives, and yet cheriſh the Monſter that deſtroys their Peace!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I have ſworn never to expoſe thee to be again inſulted by that licentious Man. Yet I cannot but wiſh he had not render'd himſelf utterly unworthy of thee. But I have given him up. You ſhall have ample Satisfaction for all the Wrongs you have ſuffer'd.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: If you can entertain a Thought of Vengeance, how are you chang'd, my Father!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Hereafter thou wilt know me better.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Whither have you ſent the Stranger and his Wife? whither are you going with the People that you ſent for? O Sir, forgive my Fears. Urg'd by your Love for me, you ruſh on to certain Ruin.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Whatever becomes of me, you are the Care of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I never knew him tranſported thus before. He's going to Sir John, and will certainly provoke him to his Undoing. Inſtruct me, Heaven, what I ſhall do to ſave him.

div.head: AIR LII. When Flora ſhe had deck'd.

sp.l: O gracious Heaven, lend a friendly Ray,
To guide my Steps, in Darkneſs loſt;
From Virtue's Precepts never let me ſtray,
But guide me ſafely thro' this dreary Coaſt.
My Love betray'd,
My Duty paid,
A ſpotleſs Maid,
Let me reſign
My uſeleſs Breath, into the hands of Death;
For while I live there is no Grief like mine.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: A Room in Sir John's Houſe. Sir John reading at a Table.

sp.l: 'Tis hard a rooted Love to diſpoſſeſs;
'Tis hard, but you may do it ne'ertheleſs.
In this your Safety does conſiſt alone:
If poſſible, or not, it muſt be done.
sp.p: A Poem on a Dwarf! what ſtrange ſtuff is here! Hey ho!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: There he ſits, poring o'er a Book, which he no more minds, than he does me.—Sir, did you call?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Who's there; Betty? Come hither. Why you look very amiable to-day, Betty.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: O Laud, Sir, you make me bluſh.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Betty, fill me ſome Wine. The large Glaſs, and fill it up.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: My Love to you, Betty.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Fill your ſelf, and pledge me.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: He's coming about again, I ſee.—Your Health, Sir.—If he would but drink a few more Bumpers; for when he had drank moſt he always took moſt notice of me. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Leave me; and ſend the Lady that came home with me laſt Night.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: Sir, cou'd n't I—I—I—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What is it you would ſay!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Why, Sir, that, that,—I don't know where to find her.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Muſt I be plagu'd with your Impertinence too! go, ſend her to me, or leave the Houſe your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: O Fathers! I can't bear it! I would I could ſend the Devil to fetch you both. [Aſide.

div.head: AIR LIII. In Kent, ſo fam'd of old.

lg.l: In vain, in vain I rove,
And if, to eaſe my Pains,

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Sir, I delivered your Letter to Mrs. Silvia.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You need give your ſelf no farther Trouble to look for the Lady. I'll go and find her my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: How, Jonathan here! This Fool loves me however. I'll divert my ſelf, by teazing him.—So Sir.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: So Madam.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Captain, methinks you look very ſcurvily after your laſt Defeat.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Now I think you look like a Dealer in Second-hand Goods, who having outſtood your Market, repents, and wou'd fain be turning the Penny at any rate.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Ha, ha, how vex'd he is! but it would fret any Man, who going with flying Colours to take Poſſeſſion of a Fort, ſhould find the Gates ſhut againſt him.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Now you want to be attack'd, only for an Excuſe to ſurrender. But you may keep your tottering Tenement 'till it tumbles about your Ears, for Jonathan.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Poor Fellow! I ſee he's horrible uneaſy. But what Woman can deny herſelf the Pleaſure of tyrannizing, when ſhe has it in her Power? To be ſure, Jonathan, you can never forget your laſt Diſappointment.

div.head: AIR LIV. There was a Knight was drunk with Wine.

sp.l: He ſeiz'd the Laſs, trembling all o'er,
On ſtorming bent, no Doubt, Sir;
But ſhe ſlipt herſelf within the Door,
And the Fool was ſhut without, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.l: But ſoon repents ſhe e'er ſaid Nay,
And finds herſelf the Fool, Sir.
For ſhe that wou'd not when ſhe may,
She ſhall not when ſhe wou'd, Sir. [Going.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: But Jonathan, Jonathan.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.l: But ſhe that wou'd not when ſhe may,
She ſhall not when ſhe wou'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.l: But ſhe that wou'd not when ſhe may,
She ſhall not when ſhe wou'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: O the impudent, pert, conceited Puppy! to leave me before he has had me! why he's worſe than Sir John. I am like to have a fine time on't truly, between 'em both!

div.head: AIR LV. The Sun was juſt ſetting.

lg.l: How kind was I us'd, e'er this Lettice came here!
But to be refus'd, ſure no Woman can bear.
By the Maſter forſaken, I'm ſcorn'd by the Man;
How was I miſtaken in truſting Sir John?
For he kiſs'd me, I grumbl'd,
But ſince that Slut's coming I'm left and undone.
But if I don't plague him for ſerving me ſo,
May I be worſe tumbl'd, worſe puſh'd, and worſe jambl'd,

div.head: SCENE XVI.
div.stage: Another Room in Sir John's Houſe.
Sir John, Timothy, Ploughſhare, and Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Perhaps it mayn't be agreeable to the Lady, to be expos'd to gratify your Curioſity.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sir, the Happineſs of our Lives depends on finding our Child. And, as we are inform'd, ſhe is here.

div.head: SCENE XVII.
div.stage: Sir John, Timothy, Ploughſhare, Dorothy, and Lettice Singing.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: My Father, Mother, and Ploughſhare here! What will become of me!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Stay, Child; whither are you going?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: O dear, dear Sir;—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay, here ſhe is; and no doubt but all the reſt we have been told is as true.

sp.speaker: Plough.
sp.p: Ah Lettice, Lettice, what have you been doing? You've ſpun a fine Thread truly. We ſhall have the whole Pariſh ring of you ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: O Child, you'll break my Heart.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Will ſhe? but I'll break her Neck firſt.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: O dear Sir John, ſave me, ſave me, or I ſhall be torn to Pieces.

sp.speaker: Plough.
sp.p: How fine the Slut is! and how familiar with the Juſtice!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ay, ay, 'tis certainly ſo. Oh you impudent Carrion, I'll be the Death of you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: To find my Girl ruin'd, is worſe than never to have found her at all.

div.head: AIR LVI. Hear me weep and wail.

sp.l: Welcome endleſs Grief,
Farewell my Gooſe and Sheers forever, ever.
Can I find Relief? No never, never.
For Grief, from Shame ariſing,
New Pains is ſtill deviſing:
All Arts muſt fail,
Diſtraction prevail,
My Brain 'tis now ſurprizing—prizing.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Friends, have Patience. What's paſt can't be recall'd, but I'm ready to make you any Satisfaction that's in my Power.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Look ye, Sir, you have utterly ruin'd the Wench. The Blame and Shame muſt now fall all upon her own Head; whereas, had ſhe been married, you know 'twou'd have fall'n upon her Husband's.

sp.speaker: Plou.
sp.p: But who do you think will have her now?

div.head: AIR LVII. Send home my long-ſtray'd Eyes.

sp.l: Cou'd you return her true and chaſte,
I'd meet her with a Bridegroom's Haſte;
But ſince, from you, ſhe's learn'd ſuch Ill,
To hate her Spouſe,
Or arm his Brows,
Keep her, for me, Sir, keep her ſtill.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: O dear! what muſt I do? My Father will break his Heart; my Mother will beat my Brains out; and that Monſter, Ned Ploughſhare, will make me the May-game of the whole Pariſh.

sp.speaker: Plou.
sp.p: Don't call me Monſter: I'm none of your Husband: So keep your Tongue to your Self.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I won't; 'tis all along of you that this has happen'd. You always knew that I hated you, and yet you would have had me, whether I would or no.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes, Huſſy, he would have made an honeſt Woman of you; but you muſt be a Gentlewoman, muſt you?

div.head: AIR LVIII. A Nymph of the Plain.

sp.l: So true, and ſo kind,
To whate'er you inclin'd,
To whate'er you inclin'd,
He had never deny'd;
But with Joy had comply'd,
To have made you his Wife,
And obey'd all his Life;
In a manner ſo ſoft, ſo engaging, and ſweet,
As well might perſwade you his Paſſion to meet.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Wife, I never approv'd of your forcing the Girl's Inclinations, and now you ſee what it's come to.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Friend, you ſeem an honeſt inoffenſive Man, which aggravates my Remorſe for having wrong'd you.

div.head: AIR LIX. Young Philoret and Celia met.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Regard my Tears, diſpel my Fears,
I'll ne'er offend you more.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: The ſimple Groom, the Steed being gone,
So ſhuts the Stable Door.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Pity my Pain. Tim. My Pity's vain.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: My Folly I deplore.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Fame that's loſt, and Time that's paſt,
What Power can reſtore?

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: Fame that's loſt, and Time that's paſt,
What Power can reſtore?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What good-natur'd Man, that was but a Spectator in this Scene, but muſt be mov'd? I thought, 'till now, the general Love of Women conſiſtent with Generoſity, Honour, and Humanity.—Falſe and deſtructive Principle! By this ſingle Act of mine, how many innocent Perſons have I injur'd? The Woman, too—the Eaſineſs with which ſhe gave up her Honour, makes her, tho' pitied, yet deſpis'd, even by me, the Author of her Ruin.

div.head: SCENE XVIII.
div.stage: To them, Jonathan; whiſpers Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha! Silvia, ſaid you? Sure you miſtake!

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: No, Sir; ſhe's in the next Room, and deſires to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
Fly then, and conduct her in.—Good People, an Affair of Conſequence obliges me to beg you would
leave me for the preſent. If you pleaſe to wait in the next Room, when that's diſpatch'd, I'll ſend for you again.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: She's here, whom moſt I wiſh to ſee; and yet, ſuch is the Power of Guilt, I dare not look upon her. Could I have thought her Sight wou'd ever give me Pain?—But, like a Wretch remov'd at once from impenetrable Darkneſs, into the mid-day Blaze, I ſicken at the cheerful Light, and fain would ſhun a Brightneſs, that glads all Eyes but mine.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: O Sir! pardon and pity an unhappy Maid: Had Heaven requir'd me to have dy'd, to have ſhewn my Duty to the beſt of Parents, the Pain had been far leſs; but filial Piety commands me to live, and interpoſe between your Power, and the Weakneſs of my good, but incens'd Father.

div.head: AIR LX. I'm Ormond the Brave.

sp.l: Your heavieſt Reſentment, ah! let me, let me bear.
In Pity to his Age, my reverend Father ſpare:
Toil, Want, and all you can inflict, I will not ſhun;
But when I think that he may be, for wretched me, undone,
Oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Welf.
sp.p: O Silvia! Never, 'till now, had I Cauſe to bluſh for any Act of thine.—Riſe, nor offer that Incenſe to an Idol, which Heaven alone is worthy of, and which, were he not loſt to Shame, as well as Honour, he muſt bluſh to receive.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Condemn me not: Can any Submiſſion be too low to ſave from Ruin ſuch a Parent? Still let me kneel.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Heaven, and all that's juſt on Earth, forbid it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
Confounded and amaz'd, I had not Power to raiſe her from the Earth.—O Silvia!—Welford!—cou'd
you ſee my Heart! how deep my Contrition! how ſincere my Sorrow! you would no longer fear, [To Silvia.] nor you be angry, [To Welford.] Vice, in all its genuine Deformities, I've juſt beheld. Virtue, in all its Charms, I ſee in you—Receive a returning Prodigal to your Arms; forgive, and make me happy.—Let the Prieſt, by honourable, holy Marriage, give me a juſt Poſſeſſion of thy Charms, and join me to Virtue, and to thee, for ever.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I came to beg your Favour for my Father, not a Husband for my ſelf. You once thought me mean enough to barter my Innocence and Virtue, for your Wealth; ſhould I now conſent to marry you, might it not be juſtly ſuſpected that my former Reſentment was not from the Love of Virtue, and Contempt of Riches, but Artifice, to make the better Terms? Virtue is Heaven's beſt Gift: Nor have they more than the Appearance of it, who ſubmit to the leaſt Imputation on their Fame, for Wealth, or Power, or Love, more tempting to a generous Mind. Think it not Pride in me, to refuſe an Obligation to the Man who would have robb'd me, of all that diſtinguiſh'd me from the vileſt of my Sex.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: To have my Love and Admiration increas'd, by what gives me Deſpair, is a Puniſhment (tho' juſt) that's inſupportable.

sp.l: With Pity, gracious Heav'n poſſeſs'd,
Taught Mortals how 'twould be addreſs'd:
Celeſtial Fair,
O ſooth my Care!
And, as my Heaven on Earth I view thee;
Lovely Creature,
Pride of Nature,
Teach me (like Heaven) how to wooe thee.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I pardon, pity, and I love thee—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: O charming Sounds!—So Heaven cheers a deſpairing Sinner, with the ſweet Voice of Mercy.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: But Heaven, when it pardons, appears above Reward, by conferring Obligations. That is not in my Power.—To refuſe them is, and in that I am determined.—Farewel, for ever.—'Tis hard—but Virtue, Prudence, and my Fame require it. Therefore, farewel for ever.—If your Return to Virtue be ſincere, you have a Miſtreſs who will ne'er forſake you; but, ever blooming, crown your Days and Nights with Joy,—when I am Duſt.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Falling on Welford's Neck.] O Welford, Welford! muſt I loſe her? You lov'd me once. Is there no Remains of Pity left? Can you behold me ſinking, and yet refuſe a friendly Hand to ſave me?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: [Embracing him.] Heaven forbids me not to pity, love, and in the Anguiſh of my Soul, weep o'er thee, my now dearer than ever, tho' too unhappy Son.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Did not you call me Son? O that I were! To be your Son, is all the Happineſs my Soul aſpires to.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Too ſoon you'll find that Name includes the worſt of Miſeries, certain Deſpair.—But, to the Buſineſs of my coming.

div.head: SCENE XXI.
div.stage: Sir John, Silvia, Welford, Goody Buſy, Goody Coſtive, Jonathan, Betty, &c.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Goody Buſy, and the reſt of my Friends who came with me, pray, walk in. Now let all here attend and witneſs to the Truths I am about to utter; and you, unhappy Youth, prepare to bear the moſt ſurprizing Change of Fortune, like a Man.—You are not whom you ſeem, and whom you think your ſelf, Sir John Freeman, Baronet, and rightful Poſſeſſor of a fair Eſtate, but an innocent Impoſtor, and Uſurper of another's Right, and my unhappy Son indeed.

sp.speaker: Sil
sp.p: What can my Father mean!

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p: This is the ſtrangeſt Story that ever I heard of.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Welford, to invent a Tale ſo vile, and ſo abſurd, to make me deſpair of Silvia, as being her Brother, is unworthy of your good Senſe and former Probity.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I will not thank you for your Aſſent to the Truth of what I affirm. This excellent Lady is not my Daughter, but the much wrong'd Angelica Freeman, the ſole ſurviving Child of the late Sir John Freeman, and Heireſs to his large Eſtate.—I read Wonder and Surprize in every Face.—You look for Proofs.—Goody Buſy, you ſerv'd Sir John Freeman's Lady, and my Wife, as Midwife.

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p: That I did to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How many Children had each?

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p: Two, a Son and a Daughter, I ſhall never forget it: they Lay-in both times together, and your Wife nurs'd both Sir John's Children.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: All this is true; but was there any thing remarkable upon the Body of Sir John's Son when born?

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p: No, but yours was mark'd under the left Breaſt with a bunch of Grapes, the Fruit, Leaves and Stalks all in their proper Shape and Colour, as if they had been growing on the Vine.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Opening his Breaſt.] Here is the indelible Mark, viſible and fair, as when the Seal of Heaven impreſt it firſt, to diſtinguiſh the Impoſtor from the rightful Heir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Too well I know it.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: If this Gentleman be your Son, how could his Birth have been conceal'd ſo long?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
That—with my own Shame, I am now to diſcover.—My Wife, while unmarry'd, attended on the Mother of this Lady, then a Virgin, and ſo far was ſhe honour'd with her Confidence, that ſhe liv'd with her rather as a Siſter or Companion than a Servant; after her Marriage to Sir John, and my Wife's to me, the Honour of their Friendſhip was continu'd; for I was happy in Sir John's, as my Wife was in his Lady's.—That we had the ſame number of Children, and of the ſame Age and Sex, and that my Wife was entruſted with the Care of theirs, you have heard already.—Soon after the Birth of this Lady, a War breaking out, Sir John, who had an honourable Poſt in the Army, went for Flanders: I attended him thither, and (as I had formerly done) ſerv'd under him as a Voluntier.—In this our Abſence, a Fever made dreadful Ravage in this part of the Country.—Of it dy'd Sir John's Lady, and quickly after his Son, (who was then at my Houſe) and my Daughter.—My Wife taking the Advantage of the Lady's Death, and our Abſence, reported, that the Son who dy'd was ours; and the ſurviving one (truly ours) was Sir John's.—Our Daughter who dy'd was bury'd as his; and his, this Lady, was reputed and educated as our own—The Fraud was never ſo much as ſuſpected by Sir John, nor any other Perſon, my ſelf excepted—I indeed, by Obſervations, which none elſe had opportunity to make, ſoon found it out, and charg'd my Wife with it; ſhe confeſs'd it, and to my Shame prevail'd upon me to conceal what I could never approve.—She dy'd before Sir John, and never liv'd to ſee her Son poſſeſs'd of the Honour and Wealth, which ſhe by ſuch wicked Means had endeavour'd to procure for him.—Thro' Heav'n's Mercy I hope ſhe reſts in Peace. But what have been my Tortures e'er ſince I conſented to conceal the
guilty Secret!—Stung hourly with Remorſe, I attempted to do her Juſtice and conceal my Shame, by effecting a Marriage between her and my Son; but Heaven, that refus'd the imperfect Satisfaction, and condemn'd the Fraud, has, you ſee, made vain the fond Attempt, nor would ſuffer her to receive that as another's Gift, which is her own proper Right.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And long may ſhe enjoy it.—I have not ſo ill profited by her bright Example, as to repine at a Change of Fortune, ſo juſt, and ſo much to the Advantage of this wondrous Pattern of all that's excellent in Womankind.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Your Juſtice, and the Moderation of your Son, affects me more than theſe unthought of, undeſired Riches: can I ever forget your more than paternal Kindneſs and Affection?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Spare me the Confuſion, that your Goodneſs gives me; look not ſo tenderly, nor ſpeak ſo kindly, but treat me as your Injuries and my Crimes deſerve.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: The Crime was another's.—Your former Tenderneſs and preſent Juſtice, tho' to the Diſadvantage of your Son, is all your own.—If you forſake me now, I am indeed an Orphan—Riches have Snares, and Youth without a Guide is expos'd to many Dangers—Be ſtill my Father.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Thy own worthy Father, were he living, could never love thee more.—But to be thy Father is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: This is your Son.—Let me be his, and you are ſtill my Father.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Do I indeed behold her heavenly Face, all clad in Smiles, and kindly bent on me? Do I indeed hear her harmonious Voice pronounce me happy?—Or does my flatt'ring Fancy, to ſooth Deſpair, form Images that have no real Exiſtence?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Bleſs her, bleſs her, Heaven! and as you have made her the beſt, make her the happieſt of her Sex.—Never did I taſt Joys ſincere till now.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: This ſurprizing Diſcovery unmade,—had I conſented to have been yours,—the Diſintereſtedneſs of my Love and Virtue could never have been known.—Heaven has made our Duty and our Intereſt one. I may now without Reproach give my Hand, where before I had given my Heart.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: What, in Tears, Betty!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: What have I loſt for want of reflecting ſooner? I'd rather have that Lady's Virtue, than her Beauty and Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Poor Girl!—Why this is to have it.—I remember on a certain Occaſion I made you a Promiſe of Marriage, if you think it worth claiming, give me your Hand.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: There it is; if you can forget what's paſt, you ſhall have no Reaſon to complain of my Conduct for the future.

div.head: AIR LXII. Ah how ſweet's the cooling Breeze.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Oh how ſweet,
All over Charms,
To bleſs my Arms,
Thy generous Virtue all Vice defeating.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: All compleat and pure's my Joy,
Without Alloy;
With Tranſport unuſual my Boſom is beating.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Deareſt Treaſure!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O Joy beyond meaſure!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: This truly is Pleaſure.
Ye Follies adieu.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: O Deareſt!
All compleat and pure's my Joy,
Without Alloy;
With Tranſport unuſual my Boſom is beating.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Love gently firing,
And ſoftly inſpiring,

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.l: Panting, deſiring, I'll Virtue purſue.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Oh Deareſt!
All compleat and pure's my Joy,
Without Alloy;
White Hours approach, and the black are retreating.

sp.speaker: G. Buſy.
sp.p: Ay, this is as it ſhould be—I could even cry for Joy, to ſee that there is ſo much honeſt Love left in the World.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Reclaim'd by your Virtue, and reſtored to Fortune by your Generoſity, I hope you'll take it as a Proof of my Sincerity, that I confeſs my ſelf concern'd for the Diſtreſs brought upon an honeſt Man and his Family by my Folly.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Your Concern is juſt and generous, like the Man I hope ever to find you—but have I given my ſelf to you, and not my Fortune? All is yours; diſpoſe of it as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Jonathan, ſend Lettice and her Friends hither.—O Madam, the longeſt Life wou'd be too ſhort to pay my Obligation.

div.head: SCENE XXII.
div.stage: Sir John, Silvia, Welford, Goody Buſy, Goody Coſtive, &c. Timothy, Lettice, Dorothy, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Unhappy Girl, I wiſh it was in my Power to make you ample Satisfaction for the Injury I've done you; but ſince that is impoſſible, I will ſettle ſomething on your Father, in Truſt for you, that, managed with Prudence, may ſecure you from the Fears of Poverty, the Rock on which you ſplit before.—You, Sir, I hope will continue with us.—The Farm lately Tenanted by my Father, with your Conſent, Madam, I beſtow on this honeſt Man, for the Purpoſes before-mentioned.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And may it anſwer your Intentions, which if it does, we may hereafter give 'em farther Proofs of our regard for their Welfare.

sp.speaker: Tim. Dor. Let.
sp.p: Heaven bleſs you both.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Lettice, as I ſhall never ſee you more, take this Advice with you.—Keep this Lady's Example in view, and you may yet excell in Virtue many of your Sex, who having never err'd in the manner you have done, look on your Fault as unpardonable.—Nor ſhall you, Betty, or Jonathan, be forgot.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Sir, if you approve of it, Betty and I have reſolved to take one another for better for worſe.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: That I do approve it, you ſhall find by the handſome Proviſion I'll make for you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Son, not foreſeeing this happy Event, I ſent for the Tenants to attend, that upon making the Diſcovery they might be ready to pay their Duties to this Lady, upon her taking Poſſeſſion of her Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Madam, what think you of inviting 'em in, to partake of the general Joy?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Gaff. Gabb.
sp.l: Such Virtue poſſeſſing,
Includes ev'ry Bleſſing,
Ev'ry Bleſſing,
Our mortal State can know.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.l: Such bright Examples firing,
Each gen'rous Soul inſpiring,
Inſpiring,
We ſcorn the World below.

sp.speaker: Plough.
sp.l: With Pleaſure while we gaze,
Transform'd, our Souls we raiſe,
For Virtue beheld the Mind renews.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: So the Sun, for ever bright,
Communicates his Light,
And adorns every Object that he views.
Since Truth to the Mind her own Likeneſs reflects,
Makes known our Defects, makes known our Defects;
Since Truth to the Mind her own Likeneſs reflects,
Let none the juſt Mirror deſpiſe.
What Virtue ſo bright but Reflection improves,
Or Folly ſo ſtubborn, but what it removes?
Reflect, be happy, and wiſe.

p.hi: Lately Publiſh'd, Curiouſly Printed in Two Pocket Volumes,

div.p:
⁂ The MUSICAL MISCELLANY: being a COLLECTION of CHOICE SONGS, ſet to the VIOLIN and FLUTE, by the moſt Eminent MASTERS.
The Man that hath no Muſick in himſelf,
And is not mov'd with Concord of ſweet Sounds;
Is fit for Treaſons, Stratagems, and Spoils. Shakeſpear.
Printed by and for J. Watts, at the Printing-Office in Wild-Court near Lincoln's-Inn-Fields, and Sold by the Bookſellers both of Town and Country.
Nov. 12, 1729. This Day was publiſh'd, The THIRD and FOURTH VOLUMES of
*⁎* The MUSICAL MISCELLANY; Being a Collection of CHOICE SONGS and LYRICK POEMS: With the BASSES to each Tune, and Tranſpoſed for the FLUTE. By the moſt Eminent Maſters.

q.l: MUSICK'S the Cordial of a troubled Breaſt,
The ſofteſt Remedy that Grief can find;
The gentle Spell that Charms our Cares to Reſt,
And calms the ruffling Paſſions of the Mind.

div.p: Printed by and for J. Watts, at the Printing-Office in Wild-Court near Lincoln's-Inn Fields, and Sold by the Bookſellers both of Town and Country.

☞ The FIFTH and SIXTH Volumes, which are deſign'd to conclude this COLLECTION, will go to the Preſs very ſpeedily; therefore all GENTLEMEN and LADIES who are willing to Contribute any NEW SONGS to this Collection, are deſired to ſend 'em as ſoon as poſſible, directed for John Watts, and Care will be taken to have 'em ſet to Muſick by the beſt MASTERS.
N.B. Thoſe PIECES which are come to Hand ſince the finiſhing the THIRD and FOURTH Volumes, ſhall be inſerted in the FIFTH and SIXTH.

p.hi: Juſt Publiſh'd, The Fourth Edition of

div.p: *⁎* The FAIR CIRCASSIAN, a Dramatick Performance, done from the Original by a Gentleman Commoner of Oxford. To which are added ſeveral Occaſional Poems, by the ſame Author.—ſine Me, Liber, ibis in Urbem. Ovid.
October 28, 1729.

This Day was Publiſh'd, with the Addition of Nine PIECES (mark'd thus * in this Advertiſement) and Adorn'd with curious CUTTS, Deſign'd by Mr. John Vanderbank and Mr. Highmore, and Ingrav'd by Mr. Gerrard Vandergucht, the Second Edition of

*⁎* A SELECT COLLECTION of NOVELS and HISTORIES. In Six Volumes. Written by the moſt Celebrated Authors in ſeveral Languages. Many of which never appear'd in Engliſh before. All New Tranſlated and Compiled from the moſt Authentick Originals.

January 16, 1729.
This Day was Publiſh'd the THIRD EDITION of

*†* Fifty One NEW FABLES in Verſe, (Invented for the Amuſement of His Highneſs WILLIAM Duke of Cumberland) By Mr. GAY: With Fifty One Cutts, deſign'd by Mr. Kent and Mr Wotton, and Engraved by Mr. Baron, Mr. Vandergucht, and Mr. Fourdrinier. Printed for J. Tonſon, and J. Watts.
